net.cloud.gfx.elements

Class ScrollView

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.cloud.gfx.elements.AbstractElement
      • net.cloud.gfx.elements.ScrollView
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Element, Focusable

    public class ScrollView
extends AbstractElement
    A ScrollView is an element which contains a single other element. The ScrollView will make it so that only a portion of the other element is visible, although this may be all of it. This is done by framing the element, and providing scroll bars (vertical and/or horizontal) The scroll bar and frame behavior can be set

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  ScrollView.BarVisibility
      A simple enum, scroll bars may either always be showing or only show when they would be needed.
      private class  ScrollView.Scrollbar
      The scroll bar that the ScrollView uses.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ScrollView

        public ScrollView(Element view,
                  int x,
                  int y,
                  int width,
                  int height)
        Minimal constructor. Create a new ScrollView which will have its top left at the given x, y location and have a final width and height as given. The scroll bars will both always show. Image assets will still be default, and hiding the frame is false.
        Parameters:
        view - The element to show in the view
        x - The x location
        y - The y location
        width - Total width of the view and the scroll bar
        height - Total height of the view and the scroll bar

      • ScrollView

        public ScrollView(Element view,
                  int x,
                  int y,
                  int width,
                  int height,
                  ScrollView.BarVisibility verticalMode,
                  ScrollView.BarVisibility horizontalMode)
        Nearly full specification constructor. Create a new ScrollView which will have its top left at the given x, y location and have a final width and height as given. The scroll bars will use the given modes. Image assets will still be default, and hiding the frame is false.
        Parameters:
        view - The element to show in the view
        x - The x location
        y - The y location
        width - Total width of the view and the scroll bar
        height - Total height of the view and the scroll bar
        verticalMode - Visibility mode for the vertical scroll bar
        horizontalMode - Visibility mode for the horizontal scroll bar

      • ScrollView

        public ScrollView(Element view,
                  int x,
                  int y,
                  int width,
                  int height,
                  ScrollView.BarVisibility verticalMode,
                  ScrollView.BarVisibility horizontalMode,
                  int firstScrollSpriteID,
                  int firstButtonSpriteID)
        Full specification constructor. Create a new ScrollView which will have its top left at the given x, y location and have a final width and height as given. The scroll bars will use the given modes. Image assets will start with the given asset grouping, and hiding the frame is false.
        Parameters:
        view - The element to show in the view
        x - The x location
        y - The y location
        width - Total width of the view and the scroll bar
        height - Total height of the view and the scroll bar
        verticalMode - Visibility mode for the vertical scroll bar
        horizontalMode - Visibility mode for the horizontal scroll bar
        firstScrollSpriteID - The ID of the first sprite in this scroll SpriteSet to use (the top border)
        firstButtonSpriteID - The ID of the first sprite in the button SpriteSet to use (the normal jump button)

    • Method Detail

      • initBorders

        private void initBorders(int firstSpriteID)
        Initialize the border images. They are sized to fit around the outside boundaries of the scroll view
        Parameters:
        firstSpriteID - The ID of the first sprite in the set (the top border)

      • initScrollButtons

        private void initScrollButtons(int firstSpriteID)
        Initialize the scroll buttons (and their images). The images are never resized, they are used as-is. This relies on the borders being initialized, already
        Parameters:
        firstSpriteID - The ID of the first sprite in the set (the top border)

      • createButton

        private ImageButton createButton(int x,
                                 int y,
                                 int firstSpriteID,
                                 int rotation)
        Generic code for creating a scroll button
        Parameters:
        x - X location
        y - Y location
        firstSpriteID - Sprite for normal image
        rotation - Degrees of rotation
        Returns:
        A newly created image button with the given parameters

      • assignButtonActions

        private void assignButtonActions()
        Set the action handler on each of the scroll buttons. The scroll buttons must have been initialized before this is called. The scroll bars may or may not be initialized, only the Optional needs to be

      • drawElement

        public void drawElement(java.awt.Graphics g,
                        int offsetX,
                        int offsetY)
                 throws IteratorException
        Draw all of the scroll view. The border, scroll bars, scroll buttons, and wrapped element view are all drawn. Much of the sizing happens here, so that it is as dynamic as possible and will adapt to changes in the viewed element.
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - How far off on the X axis this element is from the Graphic's origin
        offsetY - How far off on the Y axis this element is from the Graphic's origin
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

      • getView

        public Element getView()
        Returns:
        The wrapped element being viewed

      • isHidingFrame

        public boolean isHidingFrame()
        Returns:
        True if this view will hide the frame when neither scroll bars are showing

      • setFrameHiding

        public void setFrameHiding(boolean hideFrame)
        Set whether or not this scroll view will hide its frame when no scroll bars are visible. (Of course, for this to happen, both bars must be in WHEN_NEEDED mode)
        Parameters:
        hideFrame - True if the frame should hide when possible

      • drawBorders

        private void drawBorders(java.awt.Graphics g,
                         int offsetX,
                         int offsetY)
        Draw just the borders. These are the four borders that frame the scroll view. They are only drawn if they should be showing.
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - Offset X
        offsetY - Offset Y

      • updateVerticalBarVisibility

        private void updateVerticalBarVisibility()
        Updates the existence of the vertical scroll bar. This will essentially create or destroy the scroll bar based on whether or not it should be showing.

      • updateHorizontalBarVisibility

        private void updateHorizontalBarVisibility()
        Updates the existence of the horizontal scroll bar. This will essentially create or destroy the scroll bar based on whether or not it should be showing.

      • updateBarDimensions

        private void updateBarDimensions()
        Update the size and position of the scroll bars. This includes scroll buttons that are affected. Depending on the current layout, the bars and buttons will be placed so that they utilize as much space as possible.

      • drawVerticalBar

        private void drawVerticalBar(java.awt.Graphics g,
                             int offsetX,
                             int offsetY)
                      throws IteratorException
        Draw the vertical scroll bar. This includes all of the buttons included in the bar.
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - Offset X
        offsetY - Offset Y
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

      • drawBackground

        private void drawBackground(java.awt.Graphics g,
                            int offsetX,
                            int offsetY)
        Draw a background if there is one present. The scroll bars should be updated before this is called, it requires knowing about them. The background will be drawn as if it moves with the scroll bars, as well.
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - Offset X
        offsetY - Offset Y

      • drawScrollingBackground

        private void drawScrollingBackground(java.awt.Graphics g,
                                     int offsetX,
                                     int offsetY)
        Draw specifically for when the background needs to be drawn and appear to scroll
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - Offset X
        offsetY - Offset Y

      • drawElementView

        private void drawElementView(java.awt.Graphics g,
                             int offsetX,
                             int offsetY)
                      throws IteratorException
        Draw the wrapped element. It is drawn so that it will draw its entire self, but in a shifted way so that only the part within the scroll view will show.
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - Offset X
        offsetY - Offset Y
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

      • keyTyped

        public void keyTyped(char key)
        A ScrollView is interested in key events which may tell it to scroll. These are the SCROLL and ARROW key constants.
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Element
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Focusable
        Overrides:
        keyTyped in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        key - The key that was typed

      • topElementAtPoint

        public Element topElementAtPoint(java.awt.Point point)
                          throws IteratorException
        Determine the top element. This will take into consideration the scroll bars, buttons, and viewed element.
        Specified by:
        topElementAtPoint in interface Element
        Overrides:
        topElementAtPoint in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        point - The point to look for
        Returns:
        The top element at the point
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

      • topFromScrollBars

        private Element topFromScrollBars(java.awt.Point point)
                           throws IteratorException
        Find the top element from the scroll bars. This will look at just the scroll bars, not the buttons.
        Parameters:
        point - The point to look for
        Returns:
        The top element, or null if it is not from the bars
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If there was an issue iterating child elements

      • topFromView

        private Element topFromView(java.awt.Point point)
                     throws IteratorException
        Find the top element from the wrapped element

      • setBackground

        public void setBackground(SpriteSet set,
                          int spriteID)
        Set a background for the scroll view. This will appear behind the viewed element and appear to scroll with it. The background is tiled. If the background being set is known to be a solid color, then setSolidBackground() may be used instead.
        Parameters:
        set - The set the sprite is from
        spriteID - The ID of the sprite within the set

      • setBackground

        public void setBackground(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Set a background for the scroll view. This will appear behind the viewed element and appear to scroll with it. The background is tiled. If the background being set is known to be a solid color, then setSolidBackground() may be used instead.
        Parameters:
        image - The image to use

      • setSolidBackground

        public void setSolidBackground(SpriteSet set,
                               int spriteID)
        Set a background for the scroll view. It will appear behind the viewed element and appear to scroll with it. It will be tiled. This is more efficient than the other background method, but is only suitable for when the background being used is a solid color.
        Parameters:
        set - The set the sprite is from
        spriteID - The ID of the sprite within the set

      • setSolidBackground

        public void setSolidBackground(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Set a background for the scroll view. It will appear behind the viewed element and appear to scroll with it. It will be tiled. This is more efficient than the other background method, but is only suitable for when the background being used is a solid color.
        Parameters:
        image - The image to use

      • setRectangle

        public void setRectangle(java.awt.Rectangle r)
        Sets the position rectangle, and also updates the size of the view so that everything still appears correctly.
        Specified by:
        setRectangle in interface Element
        Overrides:
        setRectangle in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        r - The new location rectangle

      • setWidth

        public void setWidth(int width)

        Overrides:
        setWidth in class AbstractElement

        width - The new width

      • setHeight

        public void setHeight(int height)
        Adjust the height of the scroll view and update the components so that everything still appears correctly.
        Specified by:
        setHeight in interface Element
        Overrides:
        setHeight in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        height - The new height

      • resizeBackground

        private void resizeBackground()
        Resize the background if one has been set. This depends on both the width and the height, so a change in either will require a resize of it.

      • resizeForWidthChange

        private void resizeForWidthChange(int widthDelta)
        Resize the necessary pieces to make things look right after the width of the scroll view has changed.
        Parameters:
        widthDelta - How much the width has changed, negative for smaller

      • resizeForHeightChange

        private void resizeForHeightChange(int heightDelta)
        Resize the necessary pieces to make things look right after the height of the scroll view has changed.
        Parameters:
        heightDelta - How much the height has changed, negative for smaller

      • repositionScrollButtons

        private void repositionScrollButtons(int widthDelta,
                                     int heightDelta)
        Adjust the position of the scroll buttons. This does not differentiate between a change in width and a change in height - almost all of the buttons are adjusted anyways. Those that would not be affected are not, and a 0 parameter will not change them.
        Parameters:
        widthDelta - How much the width has changed, negative for smaller
        heightDelta - How much the height has changed, negative for smaller

      • resizeWidthBorders

        private void resizeWidthBorders()
        Using the existing border images, adjust their length

      • resizeHeightBorders

        private void resizeHeightBorders()
        Using the existing border images, adjust their length

      • withinScrollView

        private boolean withinScrollView(java.awt.Point point)
        Check to see if the given point is within the scroll view. This is the total area that is shown within the scroll view, not just the wrapped element
        Parameters:
        point - The point to look into
        Returns:
        True if the point is within the viewing area

      • vScrollbarNeeded

        private boolean vScrollbarNeeded()
        Check to see if the vertical scroll bar is needed (i.e. the wrapped element is too wide too be shown in the viewing area)
        Returns:
        True if the scroll bar is needed to navigate the wrapped element

      • hScrollbarNeeded

        private boolean hScrollbarNeeded()
        Check to see if the horizontal scroll bar is needed (i.e. the wrapped element is too wide too be shown in the viewing area)
        Returns:
        True if the scroll bar is needed to navigate the wrapped element

      • scrollViewWidth

        private int scrollViewWidth()
        Returns:
        The width of the viewing area

      • scrollViewHeight

        private int scrollViewHeight()
        Returns:
        The height of the viewing area

      • vScrollAmount

        private double vScrollAmount()
        Figure out how many pixels to move the scroll bar by, given the current view.
        Returns:
        How much one click of the scroll bar will be

      • hScrollAmount

        private double hScrollAmount()
        Figure out how many pixels to move the scroll bar by, given the current view.
        Returns:
        How much one click of the scroll bar will be

      • viewWidthWithBar

        public int viewWidthWithBar()
        The maximum width the viewing area will be when the vertical scroll bar is being shown. This is useful for sizing elements so that the horizontal bar will not be needed.
        Returns:
        The width of the viewing area when the vertical scroll bar is present

      • viewHeightWithBar

        public int viewHeightWithBar()
        The maximum height the viewing area will be when the horizontal scroll bar is being shown. This is useful for sizing elements so that the vertical bar will not be needed.
        Returns:
        The height of the viewing area when the horizontal scroll bar is present

      • viewWidthWithoutBar

        public int viewWidthWithoutBar()
        The maximum width the viewing area will be when the vertical scroll bar is not being shown. This is useful in conjunction with viewHeightWithoutBar() for sizing elements so at most one bar will be needed
        Returns:
        The width of the viewing area when the vertical scroll bar is not present

      • viewHeightWithoutBar

        public int viewHeightWithoutBar()
        The maximum height the viewing area will be when the horizontal scroll bar is not being shown. This is useful in conjunction with viewWidthWithoutBar() for sizing elements so at most one bar will be needed
        Returns:
        The height of the viewing area when the horizontal scroll bar is not present
